security_audit.summary: Legitimate Excel manipulation skill. Uses subprocess to call LibreOffice for formula recalculation. Writes configuration to standard LibreOffice directory. No network calls or data exfiltration. Standard file I/O for spreadsheet operations.

low_findings.title: Subprocess execution of LibreOffice
low_findings.description: The recalc.py script executes LibreOffice via subprocess to recalculate Excel formulas. Lines 31-32, 84, and 92 invoke 'soffice' and 'gtimeout' commands. These are necessary for formula recalculation but execute external processes. An attacker could potentially exploit this if LibreOffice or the script path were compromised.

content.value_statement: Working with Excel files manually is time consuming and error prone. This skill automates spreadsheet creation, editing, and formula recalculation using standard Python libraries.
actual_capabilities: Create new Excel spreadsheets with formulas and formatting using openpyxl
Read and analyze spreadsheet data using pandas
Edit existing Excel files while preserving formulas and styles
Recalculate all formulas in a spreadsheet using LibreOffice
Format cells with fonts, colors, fills, and alignments
Detect and report Excel formula errors like #REF!, #DIV/0!
limitations: Requires LibreOffice installed for formula recalculation
Formula recalculation is limited to 30 seconds by default
Cannot create or edit macro-enabled VBA code
Large files may require read_only or write_only modes for performance

use_cases.title: Analyze spreadsheet data

prompt_templates.title: Create simple spreadsheet
prompt_templates.scenario: Generate a basic spreadsheet with data
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an Excel file named sales_report.xlsx with columns for Product, Q1 Sales, Q2 Sales, and Total. Add sample data for 5 products and formulas to calculate the Total column.

prompt_templates.title: Analyze existing data
prompt_templates.prompt: Read the data from monthly_sales.xlsx and provide summary statistics including mean, median, and standard deviation for each column.

prompt_templates.title: Edit with formatting
prompt_templates.prompt: Add a header row with bold text and yellow background to existing_report.xlsx. Format all currency columns with dollar signs and thousands separators.

prompt_templates.title: Fix formula errors
prompt_templates.prompt: Run recalc.py on financial_model.xlsx to check for formula errors. Fix any #REF! or #DIV/0! errors and explain what caused them.

output_examples.input: Create a budget spreadsheet with income and expense categories
output: Added income categories: Salary, Investments, Other
Added expense categories: Rent, Utilities, Food, Transport
Added formula column for calculating net savings
Used blue text for user-editable inputs
Used black text for all formulas and calculations

best_practices: Use Excel formulas instead of Python calculations to keep spreadsheets dynamic and recalculable
Test formulas on a few cells before applying them across entire datasets
Document data sources and assumptions in comments or adjacent cells
anti_patterns: Hardcoding calculated values instead of using Excel formulas
Opening files with data_only=True when you need to preserve formulas
Ignoring formula errors like #REF! or #DIV/0! without investigating causes

faq.question: What Excel file formats are supported?
faq.answer: Supports .xlsx, .xlsm, .csv, and .tsv formats. Use pandas for CSV/TSV and openpyxl for Excel files.

faq.question: How are formulas recalculated?
faq.answer: Formulas are recalculated using the recalc.py script which calls LibreOffice in headless mode to evaluate all formulas.

faq.question: Can this skill read calculated values?
faq.answer: Yes, use load_workbook with data_only=True to read calculated values instead of formula strings.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill only reads and writes files you explicitly specify. No data is sent over the network.

faq.question: Why are formulas not calculating immediately?
faq.answer: openpyxl preserves formulas but does not evaluate them. Run recalc.py to calculate formula values.

faq.question: How does this compare to manual Excel work?
faq.answer: Automates repetitive tasks, ensures formula consistency, and can process multiple files in batch.
